AMERICAN COUNCIL ON EDUCATION
1785 MASSACHUSETTS AVENUE
WASHINGTON 6, D. C.
COPY
SENT FOR THE INFORMATION OF
Harry Skornia
January 10, 195?
Professor Thomas B. Maclin, Jr.
Mississippi Southern College
Station A Box 52
Hattiesburg, Mississippi
l 4 J357
Dear Professor Maclini
i .
I am glad to learn from your letter of January 3$ forwarded to me
by Dr. Skornia, that you hope it will be possible to install closed
circuit television at your college. I am sending under separate cover
a summary of such installations at other institutions which is not up
to date but will, I hope, be of interest to you. I am also sending you
copies of several issues of the Educational Television Newsletter which
is published by our Committee and in which you will find some additional
information regarding closed-circuit usage in educational institutions.
In the belief that you may also benefit from study of some recent
reports from Institutions which have been conducting experiments in this
area, I am sending you published reports by New York University, PennsylÂ¬
vania State University, and the State University of Iowa. Each of these
publications was cited in the most recent issue of our Newsletter which
I am enclosing.
I am adding your name to our mailing list to receive future issues
of the Newsletter, and shall be happy to add the names of any other faculty
members at your College who may be interested in receiving it.
If I can be of any further assistance, I hope you will call on me.
I hope also that you will keep us informed of your progress in developing
an installation.
Sincerely yours.
DRSiejm
Enc.
Dorothy R. Smith (Mrs.)
Secretary, Committee on Television
